forces outside of the JHU community decided that the
Hopkins gentleman had lost a good bit of gentlemanliness.

Intros Are In Order
In the few short days you have been on this campus
you have had many new experiences. The News-Letter
also is new to you. To make the News-Letter a concrete
object we have put out this issue especially for you. By
means of this paper we hope to perform a public service;
first, by reviewing some of the top events of last year so
that you may obtain a better impression of the character
of Hopkins; secondly, to introduce to you some of the
neighborhood merchants who will be able to provide you
with their various types of service and merchandise.
We hope that if you have not already done so, that
you will consider the News-Letter as one of your extracurricular activities. We have openings in every department. The main qualifications are an eagerness to learn
and work coupled with normal collegiate intelligence.
Next week the traditional Orientation Issue will be written
entirely by you, the Class of 1961. We will have a contest
for the best editorial and the rest of the stories will be
assigned by the editors. Details on this Orientation Issue
can be found on page one.
Our policy is simple: we print what we believe is noteworthy. We print words of instruction, construction and
destruction. We hope that we are the voice of the undergraduates, which no matter how "still small" is yet heard.

The alcohol situation, specfically during rush season, and
specifically relevant to freshmen,
was newly evaluated at a special
joint meeting of the IFB and the
fraternity presidents.
Prompted by what one fraternity member defined as "an
ultimatum" by the Dean, the
president of the IFB called the
meeting, feeling the recent de
cision of the IFB to continue
drinking during rushing was
passed in part because some
fraternities felt that the Dean
was bluffing.
April 5, 1957
The Inter-Fraternity Board
voted last Friday "that there be
no drinking of alcoholic beverages at rush parties held in
fraternity houses."

Football, Lacrosse Crowns
Highlight1956-1957Season
Capturing their first MasonDixon Conference Champion.ship
since 1948, the Johns Hopkins
varsity football squad compiled
a record of four wins, three losses,
and a tie, but were undefeated
in Conference competition.
Hampton-Sydney, RandolphMacon, and Western Maryland
were Conference foes who bowed
to the Hopkins eleven.
"I think one of the high spots
of the season was tying Franklin
and Marshall in the first game
of the season. For the first time
in seven years we didn't lose the
opener," said former Head Coach
John Bridgers. Bridgers accepted
a position with the professional
Baltimore Colts.
Co-captain Ken McGraw received an honorable mention on
the Associated Press Little AllAmerican. placed on the third
team of the Williamson Poll, and
placed on the All-Chemical team.

wins over Bucknell, Loyola, Delaware, and Western Maryland.
The Blue Jay varsity crosscountry team placed fifth in the
Mason-Dixon Conference CrossCountry Championship Meet, as
Morris Jones captured fourth
place in the title meet. The harriers posted a 2-4 record for the
season.
The Hopkins varsity basket-

ball team earned a berth in the
Mason-Dixon Conference Tournament for the first time in
three years, ending their regular
season with a 9-8 slate. The Jays
bowed to Mount St. Mary's in
the first round of the tourney.
The Blue Jay varsity fencing
team came within one point of
winning the Yale Trophy in the
Middle Atlantic Championship.

By STAN HANDMAKER
The Mason-Dixon Conference Football Championship, the National Collegiate Lacrosse Championship, and
a tie for the National Open Lacrosse Championship rank
as the major achievements of the Johns Hopkins athletic
teams of 1956-57.
However, the 4-0 record of the freshman football
squad, the 8-5 slate of the frosh basketballers, the 2-2
records of the frosh soccer and track teams, and the 3-3
slate of the yearling lacrossemen cannot be neglected.
The frosh turned out in numbers for all sports. Although
wrestling was dropped from Hopkins' intercollegiate pro
gram, fourteen freshmen came out for the freshman squad.

In the few short days you have been on this campus
you have had many new experiences. The News-Letter
also is new to you. To make the News-Letter a concrete
object we have put out this issue especially for you. By
means of this paper we hope to perform a public service;
first, by reviewing some of the top events of last year so
that you may obtain a better impression of the character
of Hopkins; secondly, to introduce to you some of the
neighborhood merchants who will be able to provide you
with their various types of service and merchandise.
We hope that if you have not already done so, that
you will consider the News-Letter as one of your extracurricular activities. We have openings in every department. The main qualifications are an eagerness to learn
and work coupled with normal collegiate intelligence.
Next week the traditional Orientation Issue will be written
entirely by you, the Class of 1961. We will have a contest
for the best editorial and the rest of the stories will be
assigned by the editors. Details on this Orientation Issue
can be found on page one.
Our policy is simple: we print what we believe is noteworthy. We print words of instruction, construction and
destruction. We hope that we are the voice of the undergraduates, which no matter how "still small" is yet heard.
